booleans3.caption:
Assume that a, b and c are variables of type int. Consider the following three expressions.

I.   (a == b) and (a == c) and (b == c)

II.  (a == b) or (a == c) or (b == c)

III. ((a - b) * (a - c) * (b - c)) == 0



Which of the expressions above is (are) always true if at least two of a, b and c are equal?
